sentence_results.sentence:
Facts of the case

Employees of the City of Ontario, California police department filed a 42 U.S.C.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: § 1983 claim in a California federal district court against the police department, city, chief of police, and an internal affairs officer.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: They alleged Fourth Amendment violations in relation to the police department's review of text messages made by an employee on a city issued text-message pager.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: While the city did not have an official text-messaging privacy policy, it did have a general "Computer Usage, Internet and E-mail Policy."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The policy in part stated that "[t]he City of Ontario reserves the right to monitor and log all network activity including e-mail and Internet use, with or without notice," and that "[u]sers should have no expectation of privacy or confidentiality when using these resources."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Employees were told verbally that the text-messaging pagers were considered e-mail and subject to the general policy.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The district court entered judgment in favor of the defendants.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: On appeal, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed in part.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: The court held that city employees had a reasonable expectation of privacy for the text messages they sent on their city-issued pagers because there was no text message privacy policy in place.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Moreover, the court noted that the police department's review of the text messages was unreasonable because it could have used "less intrusive methods" to determine whether employees' had properly used the text messaging service.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Question
1) Does a city employee have a reasonable expectation of privacy in text messages transmitted on his city-issued pager when the police department has no official privacy policy for the pagers?
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: 2) Did the Ninth Circuit contravene Supreme Court precedent by analyzing whether the police department could have used "less intrusive methods" of reviewing text messages?
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Conclusion
Not answered.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: The Supreme Court held that the City of Ontario did not violate its employees' Fourth Amendment rights because the city's search of Mr. Quon's text messages was reasonable.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: With Justice Anthony M. Kennedy writing for the majority, the Court reasoned that even assuming that Mr. Quon had a reasonable expectation of privacy in his text messages, the city's search of them was reasonable because it was motivated by a legitimate work-related purpose and was not excessive in scope.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: In reaching its conclusion, the Court rejected the Ninth Circuit's "least intrusive" means approach to the issue.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Justice John Paul Stevens concurred.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: He observed that the majority had not settled on one of the three approaches enunciated in O'Connor v. Ortega for determining the parameters of a "reasonable expectation of privacy."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: He reasoned that under any of the three approaches, Mr. Quon's expectations were not violated.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Antonin Scalia concurred in part and concurred in the judgment.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: He disagreed that the Court tacitly reaffirmed the O'Connor framework for determining whether the Fourth Amendment applies to public employees, arguing that it was "standardless" and "unsupported."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Facts of the case

In 2012, the U.S. Supreme Court upheld the individual mandate of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) against a constitutional challenge by characterizing the penalty for not buying health insurance as a tax, which Congress has the power to impose.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: In 2017, the Republican-controlled Congress enacted an amendment to the ACA that set the penalty for not buying health insurance to zero, but it left the rest of the ACA in place.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Texas and several other states and individuals filed a lawsuit in federal court challenging the individual mandate again, arguing that because the penalty was zero, it can no longer be characterized as a tax and is therefore unconstitutional.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: California and several other states joined the lawsuit to defend the individual mandate.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The federal district court held that the individual mandate is now unconstitutional and that as a result, the entire ACA is invalidated because the individual mandate cannot be "severed" from the rest of the Act.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit upheld the district court's conclusion but remanded the case for reconsideration of whether any part of the ACA survives in the absence of the individual mandate.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The Supreme Court granted California's petition for review, as well as Texas's cross-petition for review.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Question
Do the plaintiffs in this case have standing to challenge the individual mandate of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), which now has a penalty of zero for not buying health insurance?
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: If the plaintiffs have standing, is the individual mandate unconstitutional?
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: If the individual mandate is unconstitutional, is it severable from the remainder of the ACA?
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence:
Conclusion
The plaintiffs lack standing to challenge the Affordable Care Act's minimum essential coverage provision.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Stephen Breyer authored the 7-2 majority opinion of the Court.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: To have standing to bring a claim in federal court, a plaintiff must "allege personal injury fairly traceable to the defendant's allegedly unlawful conduct and likely to be redressed by the requested relief."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: No plaintiff in this case has shown such an injury.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: With respect to the individual plaintiffs, the Court found the injuries they alleged—past and future payments necessary to carry the minimum essential coverage that §5000A(a) requires—not "fairly traceable" to the allegedly unlawful conduct.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: There is no penalty for noncompliance, only the statute's unenforceable language, which alone is insufficient to establish standing.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: With respect to the state plaintiffs, the Court found the injuries they alleged not traceable to the government's allegedly unlawful conduct.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: The state plaintiffs alleged direct and indirect injuries.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The states alleged indirect injuries in the form of increased costs to run state-operated medical insurance programs, but they failed to show how an unenforceable mandate would cause state residents to enroll in valuable benefits programs that they would otherwise forgo.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The states alleged direct injuries in the form of increased administrative and related expenses, but those expenses are the result of other provisions of the Act, not §5000A(a) and are thus not fairly traceable to the conduct alleged.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Clarence Thomas authored a concurring opinion, praising Justice Samuel Alito's dissent in this case (describing the "epic Affordable Care Act trilogy") but stopping short of agreeing with his opinion in its entirety because Justice Thomas agreed with the majority that the plaintiffs lack standing in this case.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Samuel Alito authored a dissenting opinion, which Justice Neil Gorsuch joined, arguing that Texas and the other state plaintiffs have standing and that because the "tax" imposed by the individual mandate is now $0, the mandate cannot be sustained under the taxing power.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Facts of the case

In NCAA v. Board of Regents of the University of Oklahoma, 468 U.S. 85 (1984), the Supreme Court struck down the NCAA's television plan as violating antitrust law, but in so doing it held that the rules regarding eligibility standards for college athletes are subject to a different and less stringent analysis than other types of antitrust cases.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Because of this lower standard, the NCAA has long argued that antitrust law permits them to restrict athlete compensation to promote competitive equity and to distinguish college athletics from professional sports.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Several Division 1 football and basketball players filed a lawsuit against the NCAA, arguing that its restrictions on "non-cash education-related benefits," violated antitrust law under the Sherman Act.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The district court found for the athletes, holding that the NCAA must allow for certain types of academic benefits, such as "computers, science equipment, musical instruments and other tangible items not included in the cost of attendance calculation but nonetheless related to the pursuit of academic studies."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: However, the district court held that the NCAA may still limit cash or cash-equivalent awards for academic purposes.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed, recognizing the NCAA's interest in "preserving amateurism," but concluding nevertheless that its practices violated antitrust law.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Question
Does the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA)'s prohibition on compensation for college athletes violate federal antitrust law?
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence:
Conclusion
The NCAA's rules restricting certain education-related benefits for student-athletes violate federal antitrust laws.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Writing for a unanimous Court, Justice Neil Gorsuch upheld the trial court's ruling.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: The Court affirmed that the traditional "rule of reason" standard was appropriate in this case and rejected the NCAA's call for a more deferential standard.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Because the student-athletes who brought the lawsuit did not appeal the Ninth Circuit's ruling upholding the NCAA's rules "untethered to education," the Court did not pass judgment on that aspect of the case.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: In affirming the Ninth Circuit's ruling, the Court clarified that a prior statement made in the 1984 case NCAA v. Board of Regents of the University of Oklahoma noting that the NCAA's role in maintaining the "revered tradition of amateurism" was "entirely consistent with the goals of the Sherman Act" was not a shield against all challenges to compensation restrictions, as such rules were not even at issue in that case.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Instead, there was nothing so unique about the NCAA or amateur sports to alter the traditional method of analysis applied to claims of antitrust violations.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: In a concurring opinion, Justice Brett Kavanaugh noted that while other rules limiting student-athlete compensation unrelated to academics remain in place because they were not properly before the Court, this decision makes clear that the same traditional "rule of reason" analysis would apply.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: He concluded, "there are serious questions whether the NCAA's remaining compensation rules can pass muster under ordinary rule of reason scrutiny."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Instead, there was nothing so unique about the NCAA or amateur sports to alter the traditional method of analysis applied to claims of antitrust violations.

sentence_results.sentence:
Facts of the case

In NCAA v. Board of Regents of the University of Oklahoma, 468 U.S. 85 (1984), the Supreme Court struck down the NCAA's television plan as violating antitrust law, but in so doing it held that the rules regarding eligibility standards for college athletes are subject to a different and less stringent analysis than other types of antitrust cases.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Because of this lower standard, the NCAA has long argued that antitrust law permits them to restrict athlete compensation to promote competitive equity and to distinguish college athletics from professional sports.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Several Division 1 football and basketball players filed a lawsuit against the NCAA, arguing that its restrictions on "non-cash education-related benefits," violated antitrust law under the Sherman Act.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The district court found for the athletes, holding that the NCAA must allow for certain types of academic benefits, such as "computers, science equipment, musical instruments and other tangible items not included in the cost of attendance calculation but nonetheless related to the pursuit of academic studies."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: However, the district court held that the NCAA may still limit cash or cash-equivalent awards for academic purposes.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed, recognizing the NCAA's interest in "preserving amateurism," but concluding nevertheless that its practices violated antitrust law.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Question
Does the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA)'s prohibition on compensation for college athletes violate federal antitrust law?
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Conclusion
The NCAA's rules restricting certain education-related benefits for student-athletes violate federal antitrust laws.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Writing for a unanimous Court, Justice Neil Gorsuch upheld the trial court's ruling.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The Court affirmed that the traditional "rule of reason" standard was appropriate in this case and rejected the NCAA's call for a more deferential standard.

sentence_results.sentence: Because the student-athletes who brought the lawsuit did not appeal the Ninth Circuit's ruling upholding the NCAA's rules "untethered to education," the Court did not pass judgment on that aspect of the case.

sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Instead, there was nothing so unique about the NCAA or amateur sports to alter the traditional method of analysis applied to claims of antitrust violations.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: In a concurring opinion, Justice Brett Kavanaugh noted that while other rules limiting student-athlete compensation unrelated to academics remain in place because they were not properly before the Court, this decision makes clear that the same traditional "rule of reason" analysis would apply.

sentence_results.sentence:
Facts of the case

Since it was ceded to the United States in 1898, Puerto Rico has accumulated substantial debt, in large part due to its ambiguous legal status as a protectorate of the United States and the economically detrimental policies the United States has enacted over the decades.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Exacerbated by a series of governmental financial deficits and a recession, Puerto Rico's debt crisis came to a head in 2015, when its governor announced that the Commonwealth was in a "death spiral" and was unable to pay its debt.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: In June 2016, President Barack Obama signed into law the Puerto Rico Oversight, Management and Economic Stability Act of 2016 (PROMESA), which gave him authority to appoint a seven-member Financial Oversight and Management Board that would have control over Puerto Rico's budget and would negotiate the restructuring of its $125 billion indebtedness.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: President Obama appointed the seven-member board in August 2016 based on lists supplied by Republic and Democratic lawmakers.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: A number of creditors and elected officials of Puerto Rico have been dissatisfied with the board and its decisions and brought a lawsuit challenging President Obama's authority to appoint the board members.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The challengers alleged that the Appointments Clause of the U.S. Constitution requires that the Senate confirm high-level federal officers and that the board members were within the scope of this Clause.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The federal district court in Puerto Rico ruled against the creditors, finding the board is an instrumentality of the Commonwealth government established pursuant to Congress's plenary powers under the Territorial Clause and that the board members are not "Officers of the United States."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit reversed, concluding that the Territorial Clause does not supersede the application of the Appointments Clause in an unincorporated territory and that the board members are "Officers of the United States" because: (1) they occupy "continuing positions," (2) exercise "significant authority" that is the same or more than that exercised by other officers the U.S. Supreme Court has found to be "Officers of the United States," and (3) exercise their authority "pursuant to the laws of the United States."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Moreover, these officers are "principal" officers subject to the Appointments Clause because they are answerable to and removable only by the President and are not directed or supervised by others who were appointed by the President with Senate confirmation.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Question
1.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Does the Appointments Clause govern the appointment of members of the Financial Oversight and Management Board for Puerto Rico?
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Does the de facto officer doctrine allow courts to deny meaningful relief to successful separation-of-powers challengers who are suffering ongoing injury at the hands of unconstitutionally appointed principal officers?
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Conclusion
The Appointments Clause constrains the appointments power as to all officers of the United States, including those who exercise power in or in relation to Puerto Rico, but the Clause does not restrict the appointment or selection of the members of the Financial Oversight and Management Board.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Based on this conclusion, the Court had no reason to address the second question presented.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Stephen Breyer authored the opinion of the Court that was unanimous in the judgment.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The Appointments Clause of the federal Constitution is intended to allocate between the President and the Senate responsibility for selecting officers to hold high federal positions.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Because of this purpose, the Appointments Clause should apply to all officers of the United States, even those with powers and duties related to Puerto Rico.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: However, the Appointments Clause does not restrict the appointment of local officers that Congress vests with primarily local duties.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: When an officer has primarily local duties, he is not an officer of the United States within the meaning of the Appointments Clause.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: The Board members have primarily local powers and duties, exemplified by the fact that the power of the Board is backed by Puerto Rico law rather than federal law.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Indeed, the Board's duty is to oversee the fiscal and budgetary development of Puerto Rico and to initiate bankruptcy proceedings in the interests of Puerto Rico.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Consequently, the Appointments Clause does not constrain the appointments power as to the Board members.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Clarence Thomas filed an opinion concurring in the judgment but based on interpretation of the "original public meaning" of the phrase "Officers of the United States" within the Appointments Clause.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Sonia Sotomayor filed an opinion concurring in the judgment to explore issues the Court did not (and did not need) to address regarding the relationship between Puerto Rico and the United States.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Facts of the case

Petitioners Kendra Espinoza and others are low-income mothers who applied for scholarships to keep their children enrolled in Stillwater Christian School, in Kalispell, Montana.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The Montana legislature enacted a tax-credit scholarship program in 2015 to provide a modest tax credit to individuals and businesses who donate to private, nonprofit scholarship organizations.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Shortly after the program was enacted, the Montana Department of Revenue promulgated an administrative rule ("Rule 1") prohibiting scholarship recipients from using their scholarships at religious schools, citing a provision of the state constitution that prohibits "direct or indirect" public funding of religiously affiliated educational programs.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Espinoza and the other mothers filed a lawsuit in state court challenging Rule 1.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The court determined that the scholarship program was constitutional without Rule 1 and granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: On appeal, the Department of Revenue argued that the program is unconstitutional without Rule 1.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The Montana Supreme Court agreed with the Department and reversed the lower court.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Question
Does a state law that allows for funding for education generally while prohibiting funding for religious schools violate the Religion Clauses or the Equal Protection Clause of the federal Constitution?
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Conclusion
The application of the Montana Constitution's "no-aid" provision to a state program providing tuition assistance to parents who send their children to private schools discriminated against religious schools and the families whose children attend or hope to attend them in violation of the Free Exercise Clause.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Chief Justice John Roberts authored the opinion on behalf of the 5-4 majority.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The Court first noted that the Free Exercise Clause "protects religious observers against unequal treatment" and against "laws that impose special disabilities on the basis of religious status."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: In this case, Montana's no-aid provision excluded religious schools from public benefits solely because of religious status.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: As such, the law must be subject to strict scrutiny review; that is, the government must show that its action advances "'interests of the highest order" and that the action is "narrowly tailored in pursuit of those interests."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Montana's interest in this case—which the Court described as creating greater separation of church and state than the federal Constitution requires—does not satisfy strict scrutiny given its infringement of free exercise.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Because the Free Exercise Clause barred the application of Montana's no-aid provision, the Montana Supreme Court lacked the authority to invalidate the program on the basis of that provision.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Clarence Thomas authored a concurring opinion in which Justice Neil Gorsuch joined, opining that the Court's interpretation of the Establishment Clause (not at issue in this case) hampers free exercise rights.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Samuel Alito and Justice Gorsuch each filed their own separate concurrences.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Alito argued that original motivation should have no bearing on the present constitutionality of a provision of law, yet even without that consideration, the majority reached the correct conclusion in this case.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Gorsuch argued that the Court's characterization of the Montana Constitution as discriminating based on "religious status" and not "religious use," is dubious at best.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Elena Kagan joined, arguing that the Montana Supreme Court's decision does not place a burden on petitioners' religious exercise and thus does not violate the Free Exercise Clause.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The Court's precedents establish that neutral government action is not unconstitutional solely because it fails to benefit religious exercise.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Stephen Breyer filed a dissenting opinion, in which Justice Elena Kagan joined in part.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Sonia Sotomayor filed a separate dissenting opinion, arguing that the Court in this case resolved a constitutional question not presented, thereby violating "Article III principles older than the Religion Clause" itself.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

Question
Does a state law that allows for funding for education generally while prohibiting funding for religious schools violate the Religion Clauses or the Equal Protection Clause of the federal Constitution?
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Conclusion
The application of the Montana Constitution's "no-aid" provision to a state program providing tuition assistance to parents who send their children to private schools discriminated against religious schools and the families whose children attend or hope to attend them in violation of the Free Exercise Clause.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Chief Justice John Roberts authored the opinion on behalf of the 5-4 majority.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The Court first noted that the Free Exercise Clause "protects religious observers against unequal treatment" and against "laws that impose special disabilities on the basis of religious status."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: In this case, Montana's no-aid provision excluded religious schools from public benefits solely because of religious status.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: As such, the law must be subject to strict scrutiny review; that is, the government must show that its action advances "'interests of the highest order" and that the action is "narrowly tailored in pursuit of those interests."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Montana's interest in this case—which the Court described as creating greater separation of church and state than the federal Constitution requires—does not satisfy strict scrutiny given its infringement of free exercise.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Because the Free Exercise Clause barred the application of Montana's no-aid provision, the Montana Supreme Court lacked the authority to invalidate the program on the basis of that provision.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Clarence Thomas authored a concurring opinion in which Justice Neil Gorsuch joined, opining that the Court's interpretation of the Establishment Clause (not at issue in this case) hampers free exercise rights.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Samuel Alito and Justice Gorsuch each filed their own separate concurrences.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Alito argued that original motivation should have no bearing on the present constitutionality of a provision of law, yet even without that consideration, the majority reached the correct conclusion in this case.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Gorsuch argued that the Court's characterization of the Montana Constitution as discriminating based on "religious status" and not "religious use," is dubious at best.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Elena Kagan joined, arguing that the Montana Supreme Court's decision does not place a burden on petitioners' religious exercise and thus does not violate the Free Exercise Clause.

sentence_results.sentence: The Court's precedents establish that neutral government action is not unconstitutional solely because it fails to benefit religious exercise.

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Sonia Sotomayor filed a separate dissenting opinion, arguing that the Court in this case resolved a constitutional question not presented, thereby violating "Article III principles older than the Religion Clause" itself.

sentence_results.sentence:
Facts of the case

In Bladensburg, Maryland, as part of a memorial park honoring veterans is a 40-foot tall cross, which is the subject of this litigation.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Construction on the cross began in 1918, and it was widely described using Christian terms and celebrated in Christian services.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: In 1961, Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission acquired the cross and the land, as well as the responsibility to maintain, repair, and otherwise care for the cross.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: The Commission has spent approximately $117,000 to maintain and repair the cross, and in 2008, it set aside an additional $100,000 for renovations.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Several non-Christian residents of Prince George's County, Maryland, expressed offense at the cross, which allegedly amounts to governmental affiliation with Christianity.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: American Humanist Association is a nonprofit organization advocating for separation of church and state.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Together, AHA and the individual residents sued the Commission under 42 U.S.C.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: § 1983, alleging that the Commission's display and maintenance of the cross violates the Establishment Clause.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Applying the test established in Lemon v. Kurtzman, 403 U.S. 602 (1971), the district court found that the Commission did not violate the Establishment Clause because (1) the cross has a secular purpose, (2) it neither advances nor inhibits religion, and (3) it does not have a primary effect of endorsing religion.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

Question

Conclusion
The Bladensburg Cross does not violate the Establishment Clause.

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Samuel Alito authored the opinion of the Court, joined by Chief Justice John Roberts and Justices Stephen Breyer and Brett Kavanaugh.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Elena Kagan joined the majority opinion in part.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The Court explained that although the cross originated as a Christian symbol, it has also taken on a secular meaning.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: In particular, the cross became a symbol of World War I as evidenced by its use in the present controversy.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The Lemon test, which the Court first articulated in 1971 as a way to discern Establishment Clause violations, does not serve its intended purpose, particularly as applied to religious symbols or monuments.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Thus, when the question arises whether to keep a religious monument in place (as opposed to a question whether to put up a new one), there should be a presumption that the monument is constitutional.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Applying this presumption rather than the Lemon test, the Court found the Bladensburg Cross does not violate the Establishment Clause because it has historical importance beyond its admittedly Christian symbolism.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Breyer joined Justice Alito's opinion in full but wrote a separate concurrence joined by Justice Kagan to highlight his belief that there is no single test for Establishment Clause violations.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Rather, a court asked to resolve such questions must consider "the basic purposes that the Religion Clauses were meant to serve: assuring religious liberty and tolerance for all, avoiding religiously based social conflict, and maintaining that separation of church and state that allows each to flourish in its separate sphere."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Kavanaugh also joined Justice Alito's opinion in full and also wrote his own concurring opinion.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: He even more harshly criticized the Lemon test, arguing that "the Court's decisions over the span of several decades demonstrate that the Lemon test is not good law and does not apply to Establishment Clause cases in any of" five categories, which he enumerated.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Kagan joined most of Justice Alito's opinion but wrote a separate concurrence to note that, although "rigid application of the Lemon test does not solve every Establishment Clause problem," courts should still focus on the purpose and effect of government action in deciding whether it violates the Constitution.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Clarence Thomas wrote a separate opinion concurring in the judgment, but based on entirely different reasoning.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Thomas does not believe the Establishment Clause applies to state and local governments, and even if it did, it applies only to prevent coercive action by the government.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Thomas would overrule the Lemon test in all contexts.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Neil Gorsuch wrote a separate opinion concurring in the judgment, in which Justice Thomas joined.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Gorsuch would dismiss the lawsuit for lack of standing, arguing that simply being offended by the cross's presence is insufficient to meet the injury requirement of Article III standing.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg wrote a dissenting opinion, in which Justice Sonia Sotomayor joined.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Ginsburg argued that the cross "is the foremost symbol of the Christian faith," and using it as a war memorial doesn't change that.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Maryland's decision to maintain that Christian symbol on public land "elevates Christianity over other faiths, and religion over nonreligion."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Ginsburg additionally pointed out that an appropriate remedy for an Establishment Clause violation is not necessarily to destroy the memorial, as the majority suggests, but to transfer title to the land on which it sits to a private entity—in fact, a private entity owned the land when the cross was first erected.

sentence_results.sentence:
Facts of the case

While on patrol, a Kansas police officer ran a registration check on a pickup truck with a Kansas license plate.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Upon running the check, the officer learned that the truck was registered to Charles Glover, Jr., and that his license had been revoked.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Acting on suspicion that the owner was unlawfully operating the vehicle (based on the assumption that the registered owner of the truck was also the driver), the officer stopped the truck.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: The officer confirmed that Glover was the driver and issued him a citation for being a habitual violator of Kansas traffic laws.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Glover moved to suppress all evidence from the stop, arguing that the stop violated his Fourth Amendment right against unreasonable searches and seizures.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: According to Glover, the police officer lacked reasonable suspicion to pull him over.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: The state argued that a law enforcement officer may infer that the owner of a vehicle is the one driving the vehicle, absent information to the contrary, and the knowledge that the owner has a revoked license combined with that inference gives rise to reasonable suspicion to conduct an investigative stop.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The state trial court concluded that it is not reasonable for an officer to infer that the registered owner of a vehicle is also its driver and granted Glover's motion to suppress.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The appellate court reversed, and the Kansas Supreme Court granted review.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The supreme court reversed the lower court, holding that the inference impermissibly "stacked" assumptions and would relieve the state of its burden of showing reasonable suspicion for a stop.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Question
For purposes of an investigative stop under the Fourth Amendment, is it reasonable for an officer to suspect that the registered owner of a vehicle is the one driving the vehicle absent any information to the contrary?
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence:
Conclusion
When a police officer lacks information to the contrary, it is reasonable under the Fourth Amendment for the officer to assume that the driver of a vehicle is its owner, and if the owner's license is revoked, to conduct an investigative stop of the vehicle.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Clarence Thomas wrote the opinion for the 8-1 majority.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Under the Fourth Amendment, a police officer may make a "brief investigative traffic stop" when he has "a particularized and objective basis" to suspect legal wrongdoing.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Courts must permit officers to use common sense to make judgments and inferences about human behavior.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: In this case, the police officer's common-sense inference was that the vehicle's owner was most likely the driver, which provided sufficient suspicion to stop the vehicle.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: It does not matter that a vehicle's driver is not always its registered owner; the officer's judgment was based on common-sense judgment and experience.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Thus he had reasonable suspicion, and the traffic stop did not violate the Fourth Amendment.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Elena Kagan authored a concurring opinion, in which Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg joined, to point out that the license-revocation alert does not end the inquiry because, in a similar setting with slightly different facts, there might not be reasonable suspicion.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Kagan specifically described that most license suspensions (as opposed to revocations) do not relate to driving at all but are highly correlated with poverty.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Sonia Sotomayor authored a dissenting opinion, arguing that the Court's decision ignores "key foundations of our reasonable-suspicion jurisprudence and impermissibly and unnecessarily reduces the State's burden of proof."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Sotomayor disagreed with the majority's conclusion that seizing the vehicle was constitutional because drivers with revoked licenses in Kansas have demonstrated a disregard for the law, arguing that that conclusion "flips the burden of proof."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Courts must permit officers to use common sense to make judgments and inferences about human behavior.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: In this case, the police officer's common-sense inference was that the vehicle's owner was most likely the driver, which provided sufficient suspicion to stop the vehicle.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: It does not matter that a vehicle's driver is not always its registered owner; the officer's judgment was based on common-sense judgment and experience.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Thus he had reasonable suspicion, and the traffic stop did not violate the Fourth Amendment.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Elena Kagan authored a concurring opinion, in which Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg joined, to point out that the license-revocation alert does not end the inquiry because, in a similar setting with slightly different facts, there might not be reasonable suspicion.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Kagan specifically described that most license suspensions (as opposed to revocations) do not relate to driving at all but are highly correlated with poverty.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Sonia Sotomayor authored a dissenting opinion, arguing that the Court's decision ignores "key foundations of our reasonable-suspicion jurisprudence and impermissibly and unnecessarily reduces the State's burden of proof."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Sotomayor disagreed with the majority's conclusion that seizing the vehicle was constitutional because drivers with revoked licenses in Kansas have demonstrated a disregard for the law, arguing that that conclusion "flips the burden of proof."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Facts of the case

While on patrol, a Kansas police officer ran a registration check on a pickup truck with a Kansas license plate.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Upon running the check, the officer learned that the truck was registered to Charles Glover, Jr., and that his license had been revoked.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Acting on suspicion that the owner was unlawfully operating the vehicle (based on the assumption that the registered owner of the truck was also the driver), the officer stopped the truck.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: The officer confirmed that Glover was the driver and issued him a citation for being a habitual violator of Kansas traffic laws.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Glover moved to suppress all evidence from the stop, arguing that the stop violated his Fourth Amendment right against unreasonable searches and seizures.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: According to Glover, the police officer lacked reasonable suspicion to pull him over.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The state argued that a law enforcement officer may infer that the owner of a vehicle is the one driving the vehicle, absent information to the contrary, and the knowledge that the owner has a revoked license combined with that inference gives rise to reasonable suspicion to conduct an investigative stop.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The state trial court concluded that it is not reasonable for an officer to infer that the registered owner of a vehicle is also its driver and granted Glover's motion to suppress.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The appellate court reversed, and the Kansas Supreme Court granted review.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The supreme court reversed the lower court, holding that the inference impermissibly "stacked" assumptions and would relieve the state of its burden of showing reasonable suspicion for a stop.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Question
For purposes of an investigative stop under the Fourth Amendment, is it reasonable for an officer to suspect that the registered owner of a vehicle is the one driving the vehicle absent any information to the contrary?
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence:
Conclusion
When a police officer lacks information to the contrary, it is reasonable under the Fourth Amendment for the officer to assume that the driver of a vehicle is its owner, and if the owner's license is revoked, to conduct an investigative stop of the vehicle.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Clarence Thomas wrote the opinion for the 8-1 majority.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Facts of the case

In 2012, the Township of Scott, Pennsylvania, passed an ordinance affecting private properties determined to be or contain cemeteries.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: In relevant part, the ordinance required that "all cemeteries within the Township … be kept open and accessible to the general public during daylight hours" and that no owner could unreasonably restrict nor charge any fee to access the cemetery (the "public-access provision").
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Additionally, the ordinance permitted a Township officer to enter any property within the Township to determine whether there is a cemetery on the property, in order to enforce the public-access provision.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Rose Mary Knick owns property in the Township of Scott, and in April 2013, a Township officer entered her property without an administrative warrant and identified certain stones as grave markers.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The officer cited Knick as violating the ordinance.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Knick disputes that a cemetery exists on her property and filed a lawsuit to challenge.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Knick challenged the ordinance on several grounds, two of which are most salient.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: First, she alleges that the ordinance authorizes unrestrained searches of private property in violation of the Fourth Amendment of the US Constitution.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Second, she argues that the ordinance takes private property without just compensation, in violation of the Fifth Amendment.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Notably, Knick did not initiate an "inverse-condemnation proceeding" against the Township, which is the local administrative process for challenging a taking by the government.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: The district court dismissed all but two of Knick's claims with prejudice, and dismissed two of them (described above) without prejudice pending exhaustion of state-law remedies.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Knick appealed the dismissal of her claims to the Third Circuit.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The Third Circuit affirmed the dismissal, finding that although the ordinance was constitutionally suspect, she lacks Article III standing because she failed to demonstrate an injury-in-fact and redressability as to her Fourth Amendment claim, and that her Fifth Amendment claims are not ripe until she has sought and been denied just compensation using state inverse-condemnation procedures as required in the US Supreme Court's 1985 decision in Williamson County Regional Planning Commission v. Hamilton Bank of Johnson City.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Question
1.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Should the Court affirm or abrogate its holding in Williamson County Regional Planning Commission v. Hamilton Bank, which requires property owners to exhaust state court remedies before bringing federal Takings Clause claims?
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Does the ripeness doctrine established in Williamson County apply to takings claims that assert that a law is unconstitutional on its face?
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Conclusion
A government violates the Takings Clause when it takes property without compensation, and a property owner may bring a Fifth Amendment claim under 42 U.S.C.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: § 1983 at that time; the state-litigation requirement set forth in Williamson County Regional Planning Comm'n v. Hamilton Bank of Johnson City, 473 U.S. 172 (1985), is overruled.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Chief Justice John Roberts delivered the 5-4 majority opinion for the Court.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The Court found that the state-litigation requirement in Williamson County "imposes an unjustifiable burden on takings plaintiffs" and "conflicts with the rest of our takings jurisprudence."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Looking to the text of the Takings Clause, the Court found that the most natural reading of that provision is that the right of compensation arises at the time of the taking.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Under Williamson County, the government did not need to compensate in advance or simultaneously with the taking, but only provide a "reasonable, certain, and adequate" mechanism for recovering such compensation after the fact.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: By forcing plaintiffs to seek compensation after the taking in state court before allowing them to proceed in federal court, Williamson County imposes an "unjustifiable burden" on these plaintiffs.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Additionally, the Court expressed concern over the likelihood that a plaintiff would bring a state-court claim, lose, and therefore be precluded from bringing a claim in federal court at all.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Clarence Thomas wrote a separate concurrence underscoring his opposition to the position advocated by the township, the United States (as amicus curiae), and the dissent, that there is no constitutional violation as long as there is a mechanism for receiving compensation later.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Elena Kagan dissented, joined by Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Stephen Breyer, and Sonia Sotomayor.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Kagan argued that the Takings Clause is at its core (and in its text) different from other constitutional provisions in its qualifying phrase "without just compensation."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Kagan argued that the Clause does not forbid all takings, only those without just compensation, and the majority disregards the text of the Clause in its interpretation requiring compensation at the time of taking.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Kagan also dismissed the majority's concern over the preclusive effect of state-court litigation, arguing that Congress bears the burden of correcting errors that become evident from application of laws.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Most importantly, the dissent noted, the majority departs from lost-established precedent and disregards the doctrine of stare decisis.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Facts of the case

In 2010, for the first time in over forty years, Wisconsin voters elected a Republican majority in the state assembly and the senate, and a Republican governor.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: As a result, the Republican leadership developed a voting district map that its drafters calculated would allow Republicans to maintain a majority under any likely voting scenario.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The redistricting plan was introduced in July 2011, and both the senate and the assembly passed the bill shortly thereafter.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The governor signed the bill into law in August 2011.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Even before it was enacted, the plan faced two legal challenges, on constitutional and statutory grounds.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: A federal court upheld the plan as not violating the "one person one vote" principle nor violating the Equal Protection Clause.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Plaintiffs in this case challenge the plan as an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: At issue is whether the plan systematically dilutes the voting strength of Democratic voters statewide.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Question
1.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Did the district court err in holding that it had the authority to hear a statewide challenge to Wisconsin's redistricting plan, rather than requiring a district-by-district analysis?
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Did the district court err in holding that the redistricting plan was an unconstitutional gerrymander?
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Did the district court use an incorrect test for a gerrymander?
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Are defendants entitled to present evidence that they would have prevailed under the gerrymander test actually used by the district court?
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Are partisan gerrymandering claims justiciable?
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence:
Conclusion
The plaintiffs failed to demonstrate Article III standing, so there is no need to resolve any of the questions presented.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: In a unanimous decision authored by Chief Justice John Roberts, the Court sidestepped (for now) all of the key issues regarding partisan gerrymandering, resolving the case instead on the technical issue of judicial standing.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: For a plaintiff to bring a case in federal court, she must have Article III standing, which requires showing three elements, one of which is "injury in fact."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: To show injury in fact, a plaintiff must show that she has suffered "invasion of a legally protected interest" that is "concrete and particularized."
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: In this case, the Court found that the plaintiffs alleged but did not prove individual harms, providing evidence instead only of statewide harms of alleged partisan gerrymandering.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: The Court thus vacated the judgment of the district court and remanded for further proceedings.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Clarence Thomas filed an opinion concurring in part and concurring in the judgment, in which Justice Neil Gorsuch joined.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justices Thomas and Gorsuch did not join the majority with respect to the decision to remand the case and allow the plaintiffs a second chance to prove standing and thus wrote separately to express this disagreement with the disposition.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Elena Kagan filed a concurring opinion in which Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Stephen Breyer, and Sonia Sotomayor joined.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Kagan agreed with the findings and conclusions of the Court but wrote separately, in essence, to describe how the plaintiffs might proceed upon remand.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Kagan suggests that the plaintiffs might present more than simply a vote dilution theory, but also an infringement of their First Amendment right of association.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Such a claim, according to Justice Kagan, would not require the plaintiffs to show injury-in-fact in the form of injury to her particular voting district because that claim would be statewide in nature.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: She predicts that partisan gerrymandering "injures enough individuals and organizations in enough concrete ways .
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: that standing requirements, properly applied, will not often or long prevent courts from reaching the merits of cases like this one."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: In a unanimous decision authored by Chief Justice John Roberts, the Court sidestepped (for now) all of the key issues regarding partisan gerrymandering, resolving the case instead on the technical issue of judicial standing.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: For a plaintiff to bring a case in federal court, she must have Article III standing, which requires showing three elements, one of which is "injury in fact."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: To show injury in fact, a plaintiff must show that she has suffered "invasion of a legally protected interest" that is "concrete and particularized."
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: In this case, the Court found that the plaintiffs alleged but did not prove individual harms, providing evidence instead only of statewide harms of alleged partisan gerrymandering.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The Court thus vacated the judgment of the district court and remanded for further proceedings.

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Clarence Thomas filed an opinion concurring in part and concurring in the judgment, in which Justice Neil Gorsuch joined.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justices Thomas and Gorsuch did not join the majority with respect to the decision to remand the case and allow the plaintiffs a second chance to prove standing and thus wrote separately to express this disagreement with the disposition.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Elena Kagan filed a concurring opinion in which Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Stephen Breyer, and Sonia Sotomayor joined.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Kagan agreed with the findings and conclusions of the Court but wrote separately, in essence, to describe how the plaintiffs might proceed upon remand.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Kagan suggests that the plaintiffs might present more than simply a vote dilution theory, but also an infringement of their First Amendment right of association.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Such a claim, according to Justice Kagan, would not require the plaintiffs to show injury-in-fact in the form of injury to her particular voting district because that claim would be statewide in nature.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: She predicts that partisan gerrymandering "injures enough individuals and organizations in enough concrete ways .
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

Facts of the case

In 2010, for the first time in over forty years, Wisconsin voters elected a Republican majority in the state assembly and the senate, and a Republican governor.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: As a result, the Republican leadership developed a voting district map that its drafters calculated would allow Republicans to maintain a majority under any likely voting scenario.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The redistricting plan was introduced in July 2011, and both the senate and the assembly passed the bill shortly thereafter.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The governor signed the bill into law in August 2011.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Even before it was enacted, the plan faced two legal challenges, on constitutional and statutory grounds.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: A federal court upheld the plan as not violating the "one person one vote" principle nor violating the Equal Protection Clause.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Plaintiffs in this case challenge the plan as an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: At issue is whether the plan systematically dilutes the voting strength of Democratic voters statewide.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

Facts of the case

Encino Motorcars, LLC, which sells and services Mercedes-Benz cars, employed Hector Navarro and others as "service advisors."
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Their role was to greet car owners upon arrival in the service area of the dealership, listen to customers' concerns about their cars, evaluate the repair and maintenance needs of the cars, suggest services, write up estimates, and follow up with the customer while repair work was being done.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Navarro and the other plaintiffs alleged in federal district court that Encino Motorcars violated the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) by failing to pay them overtime wages.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The district court dismissed the claim, finding that the FLSA exempts service advisors from its overtime compensation provisions.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: A panel of the Ninth Circuit reversed, using the principle of Chevron deference to rely on a regulation promulgated by the Department of Labor in 2011 interpreting the statutory exemption as not encompassing service providers.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The US Supreme Court vacated the panel's decision, holding that the regulation lacked sufficient explanation and thus was not entitled to deference.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: On remand, the Ninth Circuit formulated its own interpretation of the applicable FLSA provision and concluded that the exemption does not encompass service advisors.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

Question
Are service advisors at car dealerships exempt under 29 U.S.C.

sentence_results.sentence: § 213(b)(10)(A) from the Fair Labor Standards Act's overtime-pay requirements?
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence:
Conclusion
In a 5-4 decision, the Court reversed and remanded the case back to the Ninth Circuit, holding that because service advisors at car dealerships are "salesm[e]n .
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: primarily engaged in .
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: servicing automobiles," 29 U.S.C.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: § 213(b)(10)(A), they are exempt from the FLSA's overtime-pay requirements.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Construing the relevant portions of the statute, the Court explained that a service advisor is clearly a "salesman" who sells services to customers for their vehicles.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The Court also concluded that service advisors are "primarily engaged in .
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: servicing automobiles" since they are integral in the process of providing maintenance and repair services to customers, even if they do not spend most of their time physically repairing vehicles.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: The Court rejected the Ninth Circuit's use of the distributive canon, as well as its conclusion that FLSA exemptions should be construed narrowly in holding that service advisors were not exempt.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: It also rejected the appellate court's reliance on a 1966-67 DOL Occupational Outlook Handbook and the FLSA legislative history, both of which the Court found unpersuasive.

sentence_results.sentence:
Facts of the case
After the 2020 census, Alabama created a redistricting plan for its seven seats in the U.S. House of Representatives.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: One of the districts in the plan is a majority-Black district.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Registered voters and several organizations challenged the map, arguing that the state had illegally packed Black voters into a single district while dividing other clusters of Black voters across multiple districts.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The challengers alleged that the map effectively minimizes the number of districts in which Black voters can elect their chosen candidates, in violation of Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, which bans racial discrimination in voting policies.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: A three-judge district court agreed with the challengers that the map likely violated Section 2 of the VRA, granting a preliminary injunction that ordered the state to draw a new map.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Alabama asked the U.S. Supreme Court to freeze the district court’s injunction, which the Court did by a 5-4 decision pending a merits decision.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Question
Does Alabama’s 2021 redistricting plan for its seven U.S. House seats violate Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act?
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence:
Conclusion
The district court correctly applied binding Supreme Court precedent to conclude that Alabama’s redistricting map likely violates Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Chief Justice John Roberts authored the majority opinion of the Court.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The Court’s decision in Thornburg v. Gingles, 478 U.S. 30 (1986) sets out a three-part framework for evaluating claims brought under Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: First, the plaintiffs must prove that the minority group is sufficiently large and geographically compact to constitute a majority in a reasonably configured district (measured by criteria such as contiguity and compactness).
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Second, the plaintiffs must show that the minority group is politically cohesive.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: Third, the plaintiffs must show that under the totality of the circumstances, the political process is not “equally open” to minority voters.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: The majority applied that three-part framework to the facts in the record and agreed with the district court that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their challenge.
sentence_results.label: contradiction

sentence_results.sentence: The plaintiffs submitted maps demonstrating the traditional districting criteria, and the district court found “no serious dispute” that Black voters are politically cohesive or that the challenged districts’ white majority consistently defeated Black voters’ preferred candidates.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Brett Kavanaugh joined the majority opinion except for a discussion of the difference between race-consciousness and race-predominance.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: He concurred separately to emphasize and clarify four additional points.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Clarence Thomas authored a dissenting opinion, in which Justice Neil Gorsuch joined in full, and Justices Amy Coney Barrett and Samuel Alito joined in part.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Thomas argued that Section 2 of the VRA does not require Alabama to redraw its congressional districts so that Black voters can control a number of seats proportional to Black voters in its population.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment

sentence_results.sentence: Justice Alito authored a dissenting opinion in which Justice Gorsuch joined arguing that the majority’s understanding of Gingles—specifically its understanding of the phrase “reasonably configured” within the context of the first precondition—is flawed, and that a correct understanding would lead to a different result in this case.
sentence_results.label: neutral/entailment
